questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A Cisco ACI fabric is using out-of-band management connectivity. The APIC must access a routable host with an IP address of 192.168.11.2. Which action accomplishes this goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It is A:
You can make out-of-band management access the default management connectivity mode for the Cisco APIC server by clicking System > System Settings > APIC Connectivity Preferences. Then on the Connectivity Preferences page, click inband.

Selected Answer: D
no.. it is D.. replacing .1 to .2

Selected Answer: A
A. Change the switch APIC Connectivity Preference to in-band management following zelya19 steps.
System -> System Settings -> APIC Connectivity Preferences - set to "inband" by default

choices.A: Change the switch APIC Connectivity Preference to in-band management
choices.D: Remove the in-band management address from the APIC
choices.B: Modify the Pod Profile to use the default Management Access Policy
choices.C: Add a Fabric Access Policy to allow management connections

questions.question_text: A Cisco APIC is configured with RADIUS authentication as the default. The network administrator must ensure that users can access the APIC GUI with a local account if the RADIUS server is unreachable. Which action must be taken to accomplish this goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Horrible question from Cisco again, both B & C will work.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/kb/b_KB_ACI-TACACS-config.html

But in the document, it says best practice is to create another local domain.

Selected Answer: D
In Cisco ACI, you can configure fallback authentication to allow local user access in case the primary authentication method (such as RADIUS) is unreachable. To enable this feature, you need to configure the APIC to fallback to the local authentication domain if the RADIUS server is not available.

By enabling fallback authentication, when the APIC cannot reach the RADIUS server, it will automatically check local user credentials as a fallback.

Selected Answer: B
Allow access with a local account (if the RADIUS server is unreachable). 
If we create an additional login domain that references local accounts it will give any user the possibility to choose to login with local credentials even if the RADIUS server is reachable.

choices.A: Associate console authentication with the “RADIUS” realm
choices.C: Create an additional login domain that references local accounts
choices.D: Enable the fallback check with the default authentication domain
choices.B: Reference the “local” realm in the fallback domain

discussion.content:
Picking C.
AES is disabled because you don't want passwords or sensitive info to be exported.

Selected Answer: C
Absolutely C based on the requirements. SCP provides authentication and encryption. And per Cisco documentation "To export hashed secure properties (passwords and certificates), AES encryption must be configured and enabled. While encryption is not enabled, any secure fields will not be exported. In this case re-importing the configuration will require all secure properties to be re-configured."
Shouldn't this be D? If you disable AES then data will not be encrypted!

choices.B:
Export destination using FTP protocol.
Disable Global AES Encryption.
choices.D:
Export destination using SCP protocol.
Use XML format.
choices.A:
Export destination using FTP protocol.
Use XML format.
choices.C:
Export destination using SCP protocol.
Disable Global AES Encryption.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A customer must back up the current Cisco ACI configuration securely to the remote location using encryption and authentication. The backup job must run once per day. The customer’s security policy mandates that any sensitive information including passwords must not be exported from the device. Which set of steps meets these requirements?

discussion.content: D and E: E for obvious reasons, D because fabric-admin role can deal with firmware management

questions.question_text: An engineer must perform a Cisco ACI fabric upgrade that minimizes the impact on user traffic and allows only permitted users to perform an upgrade. Which two configuration steps should be taken to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Divide Cisco APIC controllers into two or more maintenance groups
choices.C: Combine all switches into an upgrade group
choices.D: Grant the fabric administrator role to a user who performs an upgrade
choices.E: Divide switches into two or more maintenance groups
choices.A: Grant tenant-ext-admin access to a user who performs an upgrade

choices.B: Create an external routed network that is assigned to an EPG.
choices.D: Statically assign a VLAN ID to a leaf port in an EPG.
choices.C: Enable unicast routing within an EPG.
choices.A: Create an external bridged network that is assigned to a leaf port.

discussion.content: Extending the EPG out of the ACI Fabric: An EPG can be extended out of ACI fabric by statically assigning port to an EPG. As soon as leaf receives the traffic and determines the end point information, it assigns the traffic to Proper EPG by matching the VLAN ID on port.

Selected Answer: A
L2 External Network with ACI
This topic will help you to understand how and what methods are used to extend the layer 2 network outside the ACI fabric.

There are various methods extend the layer 2 domain beyond ACI fabric.

Extending the EPG out of the ACI Fabric: An EPG can be extended out of ACI fabric by statically assigning port to an EPG. As soon as leaf receives the traffic and determines the end point information, it assigns the traffic to Proper EPG by matching the VLAN ID on port.
Extending the Bridge Domain out of the ACI Fabric: It is also possible to extend the bridge domain by creating the layer 2 outside connection (External Bridge network). By doing so, it extend the bridge domain to the outside network.
I am really struggling trying to find why answer A is not correct? Because creating an external bridged network does extend an EPG to the outside of ACI Fabric.

Selected Answer: D
There are three ways of extending the Layer 2 domain outside the ACI fabric:
1. Manually assign a port to a VLAN which in turn gets mapped into an EPG.
This action extends the EPG beyond the ACI fabric.
2. Create a Layer 2 connection to the outside network beyond the ACI
fabric. This action allows a contract between an inside EPG and an
outside EPG. This action extends the bridge domain.
3. Create a remote VTEP.

https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/us/docs/2019/pdf/5eU6DfQV/LTRCRT-2611.pdf

comments.content: External bridged network is correct and better.

discussion.content: Isn't the answer is external bridge domain?
I think correct answer is D

questions.question_text: How is an EPG extended outside of the ACI fabric?
